MainHeading.P: The CEANN IONAID took the Chair at 2.55 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: NOMINATION OF MINISTRY.
MainHeading.P: The following nominations to the Ministry were submitted by the PRIOMH-AIRE for the approval of the Dáil:—

MainHeading.Title: NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Home Affairs.
MainHeading.P: Proposed by LIAM DE ROISTE (Cork City).

MainHeading.Title: NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Defence.
NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Foreign Affairs.
NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Labour.
MainHeading.P: Proposed by LIAM DE ROISTE (Cork City).

MainHeading.Title: NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Industries.
NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Finance.
NOMINATION OF MINISTRY. - Secretary for Local Government.
DIRECTORATE OF TRADE AND COMMERCE.
MainHeading.P: In reply to a question by M. STAINES (St. Michan's) the PRIOMH-AIRE stated that he would nominate at the next sitting a Director of Trade and Commerce.

MainHeading.Title: QUESTIONS TO MINISTERS. - WAYS AND COMMUNICATIONS BILL.
MainHeading.P: LIAM DE ROISTE (Cork City) on behalf of J.J. WALSH, Cork City) asked: “What is being done in connection with the Ways and Communications Bill?” In the absence of the responsible Minister no answer was given.

MainHeading.Title: QUESTIONS TO MINISTERS. - ANTI-CONSCRIPTION FUND.
MainHeading.P: LIAM DE ROISTE (Cork City) on behalf of J.J. WALSH, Cork City) asked: “What has been done with regard to the Anti-Conscription Fund?”

CATHAL BRUGHA (Waterford Co.): “It was the Sinn Fein Organisation which carried out the work in connection with the Anti-Conscription Fund. The whole question of Finance will arise on a separate motion.”

MainHeading.Title: NOTICES OF MOTION. - DAILY PAPER.
MainHeading.P: In accordance with Notice of Motion, T. MACSUIBHNE (Mid-Cork) moved:—
“That the Ministry should endeavour to establish a daily paper.”
The matter was referred to the Director of Propaganda.

MainHeading.Title: PAYMENT OF MINISTERS.
MainHeading.P: “That Dáil authorises the Secretary for Finance to pay to any Member of the Ministry undertaking to devote substantially his whole time to his official work, a salary, upon the President's written direction, at the rate, in the case of the President, of £1,000 per annum, and in the case of any other Minister, not exceeding £500 per annum; and to pay to any Member of the Ministry undertaking to devote the greater part of his time to his official work such salary as the President may in writing direct at a proportional rate; and that Dáil further authorises the Secretary for Finance with the like direction to make similar payment to a President-Substitute and to Substitute-Ministers.”
The Proposer mentioned that as he himself could not give all his time to his official duties he would accept no stipend, but would suggest that a substitute for him should be paid £300 per annum.
The motion was seconded by J. DOLAN (Leitrim). After discussion, it was decided on the motion of P. O MAILLE (Connemara), seconded by J. MACGUINNESS (Longford):—
“That the following Select Committee be appointed to report on the question of the remuneration of Ministers:

MainHeading.Title: OFFICIAL DESIGNATION OF DEPUTIES.
MainHeading.P: The question of the accuracy of the designation of Deputies was mentioned by EAMONN DE VALERA (East Clare) and referred to the Select Committee on terminology.

MainHeading.Title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR PUBLIC SESSION.
MainHeading.P: The PRIOMH-AIRE moved that the public Session be postponed in order that Deputies may be in a position to discuss the League of Nations and that the fixing of the date be left to the Ministry to report at next sitting.

MainHeading.Title: EAST TIPPERARY VACANCY.
MainHeading.P: On the motion of A. GRIFFITH (East Cavan), seconded by L. GINNELL (Westmeath), it was decided “That a Select Committee consisting of the three Deputies from Co. Tipperary, the HOME SECRETARY, I. GINNELL (Westmeath), JOHN O'MAHONY (S. Fermanagh), W. COSGRAVE (Kilkenny City), T. MACSWEENEY (Mid Cork), J. MCGRATH (St. James'), F. Fahy (S. Galway), be appointed to consider the question of the East Tipperary vacancy in conjunction with the question of dual seats and report at next sitting.”
The suggestion of the PRIOMH-AIRE that Thursday be devoted entirely to meetings of Select Committees and that Dáil should adjourn from this evening until 10 o'clock on Friday morning was approved.

MainHeading.Title: ABSENT DEPUTIES, PRISONERS OF WAR, AND KIDNAPPED CHILDREN.
MainHeading.P: “That a Select Committee be appointed to make a report on the imprisonment of absent Deputies and other Prisoners of War, and as to children kidnapped by English agents; the two internees in Reading and prisoners in Scotland; the Committee to consist of the three Members for Tipperary, COUNTESS MARKIEVICZ (St. Patrick's), E. BLYTHE (N. Monaghan). H. BOLAND (S. Roscommon), R.C. BARTON (West Wicklow), M. COLLINS (S. Cork), DR. HAYES (E. Limerick), E.J. DUGGAN (S. Meath), and SEAN MAC AN TSAOI (S. Monaghan).”
Seconded by J. DOLAN (Leitrim), put and agreed to.
The proposal of the PRIOMH-AIRE that the Committee of Action originally appointed by the Republican Party to deal with prisoners be ratified by the Dáil was passed with acclamation.
The following items were postponed to the next sitting in order that the New Ministry might be enabled to consider them:—
(a) The case for the Peace Conference and League of Nations.
(b) Motion as to draft of Constitution of the proposed League of Nations.
(c) Motion for message to S.T. O CEALLAIGH.
(d) Motion for message to Irish abroad.

MainHeading.Title: LOCAL GOVERNMENT POLICY — - MINISTERIAL STATEMENT.
MainHeading.P: On the suggestion of the PRIOMH-AIRE a Committee was nominated by the MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT to assist him in preparing a statement of policy. The following names were submitted and approved:—

ALDERMAN T. KELLY (St. Stephen's Green), DR. HAYES (E. Limerick), DR. J. RYAN (S. Wexford), J.J. CLANCY (N. Sligo), F. FAHY (S. Galway), A. O'CONNOR (S. Kildare), F. LAWLESS, (North Dublin), J.J. WALSH (Cork City), J. DOLAN (Leitrim), J. MAC-GUINNESS (Longford).

MainHeading.Title: FINANCIAL PROPOSALS.
MainHeading.P: “That the Standing Order 14 be suspended until November 1st, 1919, and that, in the meantime, in view of the exceptionally heavy budget required immediately and the impossibility of estimating the extraordinary expenditure to be incurred during the coming Spring and Summer, the Secretary for Finance is hereby authorised without further reference to Dáil to receive all monies which he can obtain from the proceeds of Anti-Conscription refunds, the issue of Republican Bonds, and all other sources for the purposes of Dáil, and to apply those monies to such specific objects as the Ministry (when not reduced below five in number) shall unanimously approve.”
The following amendment proposed by E. BLYTHE (N. Monaghan), and seconded by F. FAHY (S. Galway) was accepted by CATHAL BRUGHA and adopted:—

“That Standing Order 14 be suspended until November 1st, 1919, and the Secretary of Finance is hereby authorised without reference to Dáil, to apply monies to such specific objects as the Ministry (when not reduced below five in number) shall unanimously approve.”
